Finding Linear Map?

The temperature distribution on a metal plate is given by [imath]T:[0,1] \times [0,1] \to \mathbb{R}[/imath] where [imath]T(x,y)=x^2+y^3[/imath].
Write down the temperature gradient field, that is, the matrix of the linear map [imath]DT[/imath] at a general point [imath](x,y) \in [0,1] \times [0,1][/imath].

Hint:  For a mapping [imath]f:U\subseteq\mathbb{R}^n\to\mathbb{R}^m[/imath] the differential of [imath]f[/imath] is given by [imath]Df=\begin{bmatrix}\tfrac{\partial f_1}{\partial x_1}&\tfrac{\partial f_1}{\partial x_2}&\ldots&\tfrac{\partial f_1}{\partial x_n}\\\tfrac{\partial f_2}{\partial x_1}&\tfrac{\partial f_2}{\partial x_2}&\ldots&\tfrac{\partial f_2}{\partial x_n}\\\vdots&\vdots&\ddots&\vdots\\\tfrac{\partial f_m}{\partial x_1}&\tfrac{\partial f_m}{\partial x_2}&\ldots&\tfrac{\partial f_m}{\partial x_n}\end{bmatrix}[/imath] Where [imath]f_1,f_2,\ldots,f_m[/imath] are the component functions.
What would I do after I calculate all the required derivatives? @ÁngelMarioGallegos
After that you can find the matrix corresponding to the linear mapping [imath]Df[/imath] in the point [imath]\mathbf{x}_0=(x_0^1,x_0^2,\ldots,x_0^2)[/imath].
